summary: A legal memorandum from Kirkland & Ellis LLP, defense counsel for Jeffrey Epstein, detailing alleged prosecutorial misconduct by the U.S. Attorney's Office in Miami (USAO) during the 2006-2008 investigation. It accuses federal prosecutors of improper tactics, conflicts of interest, misrepresentations, and pressuring Epstein into an unprecedented non-prosecution agreement that included civil liability waivers.

persons.name: Jeffrey E. Epstein
persons.context: Palm Beach resident under investigation for solicitation of prostitution and potential federal sex crimes. The document is a defense complaint about prosecutorial misconduct in his case.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.context: Mentioned as a close friend of Jeffrey Epstein, as widely reported by the press.

persons.name: Roy Black
persons.context: Epstein's attorney whose investigator was subpoenaed by the USAO in an alleged effort to invade the defense camp.

persons.name: William Riley
persons.context: Investigator for Epstein's attorney Roy Black, who was subpoenaed by AUSA in June 2007.

persons.name: Humberto Ocariz
persons.context: A local products-liability defense attorney recommended by AUSA to represent the government's list of alleged victims in civil claims against Epstein, creating a conflict of interest.

persons.name: Joseph Hatchett
persons.context: Mentioned by a U.S. District Judge as a good choice to decide fee disputes concerning Epstein paying for a lawyer to represent alleged victims.

persons.name: Jeffrey
persons.context: Former law partner of FAUSA who filed five civil lawsuits against Epstein on behalf of alleged victims.

persons.name: Alice Fisher
persons.context: Epstein's attorneys requested a meeting with her to discuss the impropriety of the USAO encouraging civil lawsuits.

persons.name: Landon Thomas
persons.context: Senior business correspondent for the New York Times who received leaked confidential information about the Epstein case from the USAO.

persons.name: Jay Lefkowitz
persons.context: Epstein's attorney who corresponded with prosecutors, complained about misconduct, and reviewed the New York Times reporter's notes.

persons.name: Acosta
persons.context: United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida who was involved in plea negotiations, removed Humberto Ocariz from consideration, and agreed the federal government would not interfere in state sentencing.

connections.description: Described in the document as a close friendship, based on press reports.
Roy Black served as defense attorney for Epstein during the investigation.
AUSA recommended Ocariz to represent alleged victims, failing to disclose that a 'good friend' who recommended him was her live-in boyfriend, creating a conflict of interest.
Jeffrey is described as the former law partner of FAUSA. Jeffrey later filed civil lawsuits against Epstein on behalf of alleged victims from the government's list.
AUSA leaked confidential case details, legal theories, and plea negotiation terms to New York Times correspondent Landon Thomas.

events.title: Palm Beach Police Investigation Opens
events.description: The Palm Beach Police Department opened a criminal investigation of Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Florida Grand Jury Indictment
events.description: After an intensive probe, a Florida Grand Jury indicted Jeffrey Epstein on one count of felony solicitation of prostitution.

events.title: USAO Issues Document Requests
events.description: AUSA issued requests for Epstein's 2004/2005 tax returns and later subpoenaed his medical records, which the defense deemed irrelevant to the sex crime investigation.

events.title: Subpoena to Defense Investigator
events.description: AUSA subpoenaed defense investigator William Riley, seeking details of his contacts with witnesses, Epstein, and attorneys, allegedly to invade the defense camp without proper DOJ approval.

events.title: Demand for Civil Liability Waiver
events.description: FAUSA and AUSA demanded Epstein agree to civil liability under 18 U.S.C. § 2255 as a pre-condition to defer federal prosecution, including waiving rights and agreeing to pay damages to undisclosed individuals.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement Executed
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein and the USAO executed a Non-Prosecution Agreement. Prosecutors allegedly promised confidentiality but soon notified three alleged victims of its terms.

events.title: Deposition of Initial Complainant
events.description: Epstein's lawyers took a deposition of the initial state complainant, who admitted lying to Epstein about being an adult, undermining the basis for federal charges.

locations: West Palm Beach Division of the Southern District of Florida
keyFacts: The defense alleges a pattern of prosecutorial misconduct by the Miami U.S. Attorney's Office, including unauthorized subpoenas, conflicts of interest, and misrepresentations to the court and defense.
Prosecutors demanded Epstein agree to unprecedented civil liability terms—waiving rights and agreeing to pay damages to undisclosed 'victims'—as a condition to avoid federal indictment.
AUSA recommended attorney Humberto Ocariz to represent alleged victims, failing to disclose that the recommending 'good friend' was her live-in boyfriend, a clear conflict of interest.
The USAO leaked confidential case details, including plea negotiation terms and legal theories, to New York Times reporter Landon Thomas.
FAUSA's former law partner, Jeffrey, filed multiple civil lawsuits against Epstein on behalf of alleged victims from the government's list, shortly after the non-prosecution agreement.
